title: Financial auditor or accountant
shortSummary: Examine and analyze financial records to ensure accuracy and compliance, prepare financial statements and reports, design or maintain accounting systems, and provide advice on taxation and internal controls.
typicalEmployers: Public practice accounting firms, corporate finance departments, government ministries, Indigenous organizations, non profit agencies, and small or medium sized businesses.

title: Accounting technician or bookkeeper
shortSummary: Maintain complete sets of books, record and reconcile financial transactions, prepare trial balances and basic financial reports, and support accountants with day to day accounting tasks.
typicalEmployers: Public practice firms, small and medium businesses, retail and service companies, non profit and Indigenous organizations, and municipal or regional governments.

title: Accounting or finance clerk
shortSummary: Calculate, prepare, and process invoices, accounts payable and receivable, payroll inputs, budgets, and other financial records following established procedures.
typicalEmployers: Private companies, health and education organizations, Indigenous governments, local and regional governments, and non profit agencies.

title: Database analyst or data administrator
shortSummary: Design and support data management solutions, create and maintain databases, apply data standards and security policies, and help organizations turn raw data into reliable information.
typicalEmployers: IT consulting firms, corporate IT departments, government agencies, health and education organizations, and large Indigenous or community based organizations with complex data needs.

title: Project coordinator or administrative officer
shortSummary: Coordinate office and project administration, track timelines and budgets, prepare reports and documentation, support procurement and logistics, and help teams deliver projects on schedule.
typicalEmployers: Municipal and regional governments, health and education organizations, construction and resource companies, non profit and Indigenous organizations, and professional services firms.

title: Business systems specialist or business analyst
shortSummary: Analyze business processes and systems, document requirements, test and implement system changes, and translate business needs into technical solutions that improve performance.
typicalEmployers: IT consulting and software firms, corporate IT departments, government ministries and Crown corporations, financial institutions, and larger Indigenous or community organizations.

title: Administrative assistant
shortSummary: Provide administrative and clerical support such as preparing documents and correspondence, scheduling, data entry, record keeping, and front line communication with clients or students.
typicalEmployers: Offices in every sector including health care, education, government, non profit, Indigenous organizations, and private sector companies.

title: Administrative officer or office manager
shortSummary: Oversee and coordinate office procedures, supervise support staff, manage records and contracts, support budgets and purchasing, and recommend improvements to administrative systems.
typicalEmployers: Small and medium businesses, government departments, school districts, health organizations, Indigenous governments, and community based agencies.

title: Human resources or recruitment officer
shortSummary: Plan and carry out staffing activities including posting positions, screening applicants, coordinating interviews, checking references, and supporting onboarding while ensuring fair and inclusive practices.
typicalEmployers: Medium and large employers in health, education, government, manufacturing, services, Indigenous organizations, and specialized staffing or recruitment firms.

title: Financial sales representative
shortSummary: Sell and explain banking and investment products such as accounts, loans, lines of credit, and basic investment options to individuals and small businesses.
typicalEmployers: Banks, credit unions, trust companies, and other financial institutions that serve individuals and small and medium businesses.

title: Small business owner or self employed entrepreneur
nocTitle: Small business owner or self employment (various NOC codes)
shortSummary: Own and operate a small business such as a retail shop, service company, consulting practice, or online venture, often performing management, marketing, finance, and customer service tasks personally.
typicalEmployers: Self employment in sectors such as retail, tourism, trades, transportation, technology, creative industries, and community based services.

title: Marketing or public relations officer
nocTitle: Professional occupations in advertising, marketing and public relations
shortSummary: Develop and deliver marketing and communication plans, manage social media and campaigns, prepare promotional materials, and support public relations or fundraising activities.
typicalEmployers: Private companies, tourism and economic development agencies, non profit and Indigenous organizations, post secondary institutions, and marketing or communications firms.

title: Restaurant or food service manager
shortSummary: Plan, organize, and direct the operations of restaurants, cafes, catering services, or other food and beverage establishments, including staffing, budgets, inventory, and guest service.
typicalEmployers: Independent restaurants, franchise chains, hotel food and beverage departments, catering companies, and institutional food service providers.

title: Accommodation service manager
shortSummary: Oversee the operations of hotels, motels, lodges, or other accommodation facilities, ensuring effective front desk, housekeeping, maintenance, and guest services.
typicalEmployers: Hotels, motels, resorts, lodges, student residences, and other accommodation establishments in urban, rural, and tourism based communities.

title: Food service supervisor
shortSummary: Supervise, coordinate, and schedule staff who prepare and serve food, train team members, help manage inventory and quality, and make sure food safety standards are followed.
typicalEmployers: Restaurants, quick service outlets, cafeterias, hospitals and care facilities, catering companies, and other food service operations.

title: Hotel front desk clerk or guest services agent
shortSummary: Handle check in and check out, take reservations, respond to guest questions and requests, process payments, and provide information about hotel services and local attractions.
typicalEmployers: Hotels, motels, inns, resorts, lodges, and other accommodation providers in cities, small towns, and tourism destinations.

title: Compensation or staffing clerk
shortSummary: Support human resources teams by maintaining records related to staffing, recruitment, training, performance reviews, compensation changes, and benefits.
typicalEmployers: Human resources departments in government, health care, education, large private companies, and Indigenous and community organizations.

title: Customer service representative
nocTitle: Other customer and information services representatives
shortSummary: Respond to customer questions, provide information about products and services, handle orders and payments, and resolve basic concerns in person, online, or by phone.
typicalEmployers: Retailers, utilities, telecommunications providers, financial institutions, public sector contact centres, and education or community service organizations.

title: Junior business or market analyst
nocTitle: Business development officers and market researchers and analysts
shortSummary: Collect and analyze data about markets, customers, or economic trends, prepare reports and dashboards, and support projects that aim to grow programs, services, or business activity.
typicalEmployers: Government and regional development agencies, market research firms, banks, large corporations, Indigenous economic development organizations, and consulting companies.
